issues.title: FIDO has already defined an EKU for similar usage; review needed
issues.author: jpfiset

comments.author: jpfiset
comments.body:
According to the documentation, there are provisions to ensure that a TPM attestation is supported with a certificate that contains the EKU OID 2.23.133.8.3. This OID is specific to TPM and can not be reused for the purpose of our new specification.

The other attestation methods (packed and android) do not include EKUs specific for this purpose.

issues.title: DICE may already have suitable EKUs for this purpose
issues.author: jpfiset
issues.body:
Ref: https://trustedcomputinggroup.org/wp-content/uploads/DICE-Certificate-Profiles-v1.1_pub.pdf (sections 5.1.5.3, 5.1.5.4, 5.1.5.5 and 5.1.5.6)

Should review if one of those is applicable for the intended purpose.

comments.author: jpfiset
comments.body: DICE has defined four EKUs for attestation keys. However, they are very specialized in scope and do not apply for the work we are currently doing.

comments.author: jpfiset
comments.body:
The four OIDs defined in DICE:
- Initial Attestation OID : 2.23.133.5.4.100.8
- Local Attestation OID : 2.23.133.5.4.100.9
- Initial Assertion OID : 2.23.133.5.4.100.10
- Local Assertion OID : 2.23.133.5.4.100.11

issues.title: Fixes needed to ASN.1 relatinng to OIDs
issues.author: jpfiset
issues.body:
Russ Housley provided the following comment:

The ASN.1 module needs to begin with a module name and identifier:

   AttestationEKU-2025
      { iso(1) identified-organization(3) dod(6) internet(1)
        security(5) mechanisms(5) pkix(7) id-mod(0)
        id-mod-attestation-eku-2025(TBD0) }

The IANA considerations needs to say what registry to use.

   For the ASN.1 module found in Appendix A, IANA is requested to assign
   an object identifier for the module identifier (TBD0) with a
   description of "id-mod-attestation-eku-2025".  This should be allocated in the
   "SMI Security for PKIX Module Identifier" registry (1.3.6.1.5.5.7.0).

   For the ASN.1 module found in Appendix A, IANA is requested to assign
   an object identifier for the extended key usage value (XX) with a
   description of "id-kp-attestationKey".  This should be allocated in the
   "SMI Security for PKIX Extended Key Purpose" registry (1.3.6.1.5.5.7.3).

issues.title: Comments for Corey Bonnell
issues.author: jpfiset
issues.body:
1. The draft specifies that the digitalSignature KU MUST be set, but it is 
unclear whether other bits can be set. It would be good to clarify.
2. The draft doesn't specify whether the EKU extension should be critical. It 
would be good to clarify.
3. The draft currently says, "While assessing an endorsement provided this 
way, a Verifier must follow all practices to validate the veracity of the 
certificate.". I think this needs to be more specific. I believe it's saying 
that certification path validation MUST be performed, but it would be good if 
this is made explicit.

comments.author: mstjohns
comments.body:
Actually, an attestation key MUST only be used for attestation. And that's generally enforced by the attestation engine.  Allowing the key to do a general digitalSignature is problematic as you can't differentiate a real attestation from one genned up by the key owner.  This should be proven in some way to the CA that is issuing the AK cert.  But that way is out of scope for this document.

In TPM2.0 terms, this is a key with the "restricted" bit set. 

So the EKU can only have the "id-kp-attestationKey" key purpose OID.  

Of the possible bits in KeyUsage, I would suggest that only the "nonRepudiation" bit is appropriate, but it's maybe even more appropriate to include a KeyUsage extension with no bits set.  (If you omit KeyUsage, any key purpose listed is valid).  "digitalSignature" assumes this key can be used for anything other than certificate and crl signatures, and that's not accurate.  What it can verify is very tightly controlled. 

With respect to path validation, it may be worthwhile to define a CertificationPolicies OID of "id-cp-attestation" to be issued to the issuing CA (and the AK certificate...).  This allows for a chain of authority restricting various CAs from issuing AK certificates.  E.g. an AK certificate path validation result must include the "id-cp-attestation" policy in addition to the id-kp-attestationKey EKU for the RP to trust the key for use in validating an attestation.

Lastly, I'd delete the requirement that the AK must not be controlled by anyone other than the attester.  In the first place, this isn't something that the CA can verify.  In the second place, I would expect some versions of this to enroll an AK that's available to anyone on a given HSM to attest the state of the HSM.  That might be issued by the HSM vendor or some third party.

comments.author: jpfiset
comments.body:
```
So the EKU can only have the "id-kp-attestationKey" key purpose OID.
```
One must account for other EKU such as the ones assigned to TPM attestation keys. Both could be present since they are compatible.

```
This should be proven in some way to the CA that is issuing the AK cert. But that way is out of scope for this document.

In TPM2.0 terms, this is a key with the "restricted" bit set.
```
I agree that it is out of scope of the document, this is why it is not defined. Yet, the CA shall use some form of attestation to verify that the key is usable only by the Attester.

comments.body: Mike, if you feel your comments are not addressed, please raise a different issue. I would like to close this issue as Corey's comments have been addressed.
